title: Chapter 1 â€“ Practice: Your First SQL Queries
description: Hands-on missions for chapter 1 to master basic SELECT queries and SQL fundamentals.

hints: Use the SELECT keyword followed by the wildcard *
Don't forget the FROM clause to specify the table name
Remember to end your statement with a semicolon (;)
solution.notes: Write your very first SQL query to see data from a table! Query must select all columns from the 'hackers' table using the wildcard (*).

hints: After SELECT, list the column names separated by a comma
The syntax is: SELECT column1, column2 FROM table_name;
Make sure to spell the column names correctly
solution.notes: Learn to retrieve only the columns you need instead of all data. Write a query to select only the 'username' and 'level' columns from the 'hackers' table.

hints: SELECT just one column name
Don't use commas if you're only selecting one column
Syntax: SELECT column_name FROM table_name;
solution.notes: Sometimes you only need one piece of information from a table. Write a query to select only the 'username' column from the 'hackers' table.

hints: Use SELECT * to get all columns
The table name is 'skills'
Remember the semicolon at the end
solution.notes: Practice selecting data from a different table to get comfortable with the basics. Write a query to select all columns from the 'skills' table.

solution.expectedQuery: SELECT skill_name, category, difficulty FROM skills;
hints: List all three column names separated by commas
Make sure there's no comma after the last column name
Order doesn't matter for now, but try to match: skill_name, category, difficulty
solution.notes: Master selecting multiple columns by retrieving three different pieces of information. Write a query to select 'skill_name', 'category', and 'difficulty' columns from the 'skills' table.

hints: Use SELECT followed by the two column names
Separate columns with a comma
The table name is 'projects'
solution.notes: Practice with a third table to reinforce your SELECT skills. Write a query to select 'project_name' and 'status' columns from the 'projects' table.

hints: Look for missing punctuation between column names
Don't forget the semicolon at the end
Column names need to be separated by commas
solution.notes: Find and fix common SQL syntax errors to become a better debugger. Fix this query: SELECT username level FROM hackers

solution.expectedQuery: SELECT username, level, xp_points FROM hackers;
hints: Think about what information a leaderboard would show
Select the three columns that show player progress
Remember to separate column names with commas
solution.notes: Create queries based on real-world scenarios to apply what you've learned. You need to create a leaderboard. Write a query to get 'username', 'level', and 'xp_points' from the 'hackers' table.
